publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Wrote in ye year 1728
After venting all my Spight,
Tell me what I have to write.
Every Error I wḍfind
Thro' the Mazes of your Mind,
Have my busy muse employ'd,
Till yẹ company is cloy'd;
Are you positive, & fretfull,
Heedless, ignorant, forgetfull;
These, & twenty follies more
I have often told before.Hearken what my Lady says,
Have I nothing then to praise?
Ill it fitts you to be witty,
Where a fault shḍ move your Pity;
If you think me too conceited,
On to passion quickly heated,
If my wandring head be less
Set on reading, than on dress,
If I alway seem too dull to ye,
I can solve ye difficulty.You wḍ teach me to be wise,
Truth & Honour how to prize,
How to shine in conversation,
And with credit fill my Station,
How to relish notions high,
How to live, & how to die.
But it was decreed by fate
Mṛ Dean, you came too late;
Well I know, you can discern,
I am now too old to learn,
Follies from my Youth instill'd
Have my Soul intirely fill'd,
In my head, & heart, they center,
Nor will let your Lessons enter.
Bred a fondling, & an Heiress,
Dress'd like any Lady Mayress,
Cocker'd by yẹ Servants round,
Was too good to touch ye: ground,
Thought the Life of every Lady
Shḍ be one continued Play-day,
Balls, & masquerades, & Shows,
Visits, Plays, & powdred Beaux.Thus you have my case at large,
And may now Pform your Charge,
Those Materials I have furnish'd,
When by you refin'd, & burnish'd,
Must, that all yẹ World may know'em,
Be reduc'd into a poem;
But I beg, suspend a while
That same paultry, Burlesque Style,
Drop for once your constant Rule
Turning all to Ridicule,
Teaching others how to ape ye,
Court, nor Parliament can scape ye,
Treat yẹ Publick & your friends
Both alike, while neither mends.
Sing my praise in strain sublime,
Treat not me with doggrel Rhyme,
'Tis but just you shḍ produce
With each fault, each fault's excuse,
Not to publish every trifle,
And my few perfections Stifle;
With some gifts at least endow me,
Which my very foes allow me,
Am I spightfull, proud, unjust?
Did I ever break my trust?
Which of all your modern Dames
Censures less or less defames?
In good manners am I faulty?
Can you call me rude or haughty?
Did I e'er my Mite withhold
From the impotent & old?
When have I esteem express'd
For a Coxcomb gaily dress'd?
Do I, like the female tribe,
Think it witt to fleer & Jibe?
Who with less designing Ends
Kindly entertains their friends?
With good words, & count'nance sprightly
Strive to treat them all politely;
Think not cards my chief Diversion,
'Tis a most unjust aspersion,
Never knew I any good in 'em,
But to doze my head like Lodanum,
We by play as Men by Dr: overthinking,
Pass our nights, to drive out thinking;
From my ailments give me leisure,
I shall read, & think, with Pleasure,
Conversation learn to relish,
And with books my mind embellish.Now, methinks, I hear you cryMṛ Dean, you must reply;
Madam, I allow 'tis true,
All these praises are your due;
You, like some acute Philosopher,
Ev'ry fault have drawn a gloss over,
Placing in the strongest light
All your Virtues to my sight;
Though you lead a blameless life,
Live an humble, prudent Wife
Answer all domestiq: ends,
What is this to us your friends?
Though your Children by a Nod
Stand in awe without a Rod,
Though, by your obliging Sway,
Servants love you, & obey,
Though you treat us with a Smile,
Clear your Looks, & smooth your Style,
Load our plates from ev'ry Dish;
This is not the thing we wish.
Colonel ────may be your Debtor,
We expect employment better;
You must learn, if you wḍ gain us,
With good sense to entertain us.
Scholars, when good Sense describing
Call it tasting, & imbibing,
Metaphorick meat, & drink,
Is to understand, & think,
We may carve for others thus,
And let others carve for us,
To discourse, & to attend,
Is to help yourself, & friend,
Conversation is but carving,
Carve for all yourself, is Starving.
Give no more to ev'ry guest,
Than he's able to digest,
Give him alway of ye prime,
And but little at a time,
Carve to all but just enough,
Let them neither starve, nor stuff,
And that you may have your due,
Let your Neibours carve for you.To conclude this long essay,
Pardon if I disobey
Nor against my nat'ral vein
Treat you in heroick Strain,
I, as all yẹ Parish knows,
Hardly can be grave in prose,
Still to lash, & lashing smile,
Ill befitts a lofty Style.
From yẹ Planet of my Birth
I encounter vice with Mirth.
Wicked Ministers of State
I can easier scorn than hate,
And I find it answers right,
Scorn torments them more than Spight,
All the vices of a Court
Do only serve to make me sport.
Were I in some foreign realm,
Which all vices overwhelm,
Where a Monkey wears a Crown,
Must I tremble at his frown?
Could I not thro' all his Ermine
Spy ye strutting, chatt'ring Vermine,
Safely write a smart Lampoon
To expose yẹ brisk Baboon.When my muse officious ventures
On yẹ nations representors,
Teaching, by what golden rules,
Into knaves they turn their fools;
How yẹ helm is rul'd by Walpole,
At whose oars, like Slaves, they all pull.
Let yẹ Vessels split on Shelves,
With yẹ freight inrich themselves,
Safe within my little Wherry,
All their madness makes me merry,
Like the Watermen of Thames,
I row by, & call them names,
Like the ever-laughing Sage,
In a Iest, I spend my Rage,
Though it must be understood,
I wḍ hang them if I cou'd;
If I can but fill my Nitch,
I attempt no higher pitch,
Leave to D'anvers, & his mate,
Maxims wise to rule the State,
Poultney deep, accomplish'd St: Iohn's,
Scourge the Villains with a Venge'ance
Let me, tho' ye: smell be noisome,
Strip their Bums, let Caleb hoise'em,
Then apply Alecto's Whip,
Till they wriggle, howl, & whip.Duce is in you, Mr: Dean,
What can all this passion mean?
Mention courts, you'll ne'er be quiet,
On Corruptions running riot,
And as it befits your Station
Come to use, & Application.
Nor with Senate keep a fuss,
I submit & answer thus.If yẹ Machinations brewing
To complete ye: publick ruin,
Never once coḍ have the power
To affect me half an hour,
Sooner wḍ I write in Buskins
Mournfull Elegies on Blueskins.
If I laugh at Whig, & Tory,
I conclude a Fortiori.
All your Eloquence will scarce
Drive me from my fav'rite farce.
Thus I must insist on──for as
It is well observ'd by Horace,
Ridicule has greater Power
To reform yẹ world, than Sour.
Horses thus, let Iockeys Judge else,
Switches better guide than Cudgels
Bastings heavy, dry, obtuse,
Only dulness can produce
While a little gentle Jerking
Sets yẹ Spirits all a working.
Thus I find it by experiment
Scolding moves you, less than Merriment
I may storm, & rage in vain,
It but stupifies your brain,
But with raillery to nettle
Sets your thoughts upon their mettle,
Gives Imagination scope,
Never lets your mind elope,
Drives out brangling, & Contention,
Brings in reason, & Invention;
For your sake as well as mine,
I the lofty stile decline,
I shḍ make a figure Scurvy,
And your head turn topsy-turvy,
I who love to have a fling
Both at Senate-house & K────
That they might some better way tread
To avoid the Publick Hatred,
Thought no method more comodious,
Than to shew their Vice is odious,
Which I chose to make appear
Not by anger, but a Sneer,
As my method of reforming
Is by laughing, not by storming,
(For my friends have always thought
Tenderness my greatest fault)
Wod: you have me change my Style
On your faults no longer smile,
But to patch up all your Quarrels
Quote you texts from Plutarch's Morals,
Or from Solomon produce
Maxims teaching wisdom's use,
If I treat you, like a crown'd-head,
You have cheap enough compounded,
Can you put in higher Claims,
Than the owner of Sṭ James;
You are not so great a greivance
As the Hierlings of Sṭ Stephens,
You are of a lower Class,
Than my friend Sir Robert Brass;
None of these have mercy found,
I have laugh'd, & lash'd them round.Have you seen a Rocket fly?
You wḍ swear it peirc'd ye Skie;
It but reach'd ye middle Air,
Bursting into peices there.
Thousand sparkles falling down
Light on many a Coxcomb's crown,
See, what Mirth ye Sport creates
Singes hair, but brakes no pates.
Thus shḍ I attempt to climb,
Treat you in a Style sublime,
Such a Rocket is my muse.
Shḍ I lofty numbers chuse,
E'er I reach'd Parnassus top,
I shḍ burst, & bursting drop;
All my fire woḍ fall in scraps,
Give your head some gentle raps,
Only make it smart a while,
Then cou'd I forbear to smile?
When I found the tingling pain
Entring warm your frigid Brain,
Make you able upon sight
To decide of wrong & right,
Talk with sense what e'er you please on,
Learn to relish Truth, & reason;
Thus we both shou'd gain our Prize.
I to laugh & you grow wise.629-800Z
